subject: Logging and Object IDs

messageBody:
Hi,

So I've been using JUnitDoclet to generate test shells for some
existing code, and I think I've finally picked up the point that the
setUp and tearDown methods along with the test constructor are all
called for each individual test method in the test class.

I can see the logic behind this is that each test should be conducted
standalone so to speak. I can see from the FAQ
http://junit.sourceforge.net/doc/faq/faq.htm#organize_3 that there is
a way to write code such that setUp or tearDown methods are called
only once, but that this is not encouraged.

My situation is that I was just adding logging support to my classes,
and that the classes are set up so that each time a class is created
it is handed a unique id. As a consequence if I have 7 test methods
in my class, the logging system gets initialized 7 times (since the
init() method is in setUp) and 7 objects with 7 different object ids
get created, one for each test method.

I can see that conceivably there might be interactions such that the
multiple re-initializations help make the tests more robust, but I'm
not sure quite what they are.

So my question is, does initialization of a logging system count as
something that deserves a unique setUp method?

And if I want to conduct a series of tests on one object with a
particular id, should I try and create the object in a unique setUp
method, or should I create single test methods that test a series of
operations on a particular object?

I am guessing that really I should have multiple test methods, to
test each operation and then other tests to test series of combined
operations. I am then concerned about whether these more complex
tests should be in the same test class or in a different one.
Perhaps unit testing should only ever test a single method at a time,
and the desire to test a series of them at once suggests there should
be another method, or object that can encapsulate the complex
operation, and then this can be tested in another class?

Thanks in advance.

CHEERS> SAM
